content.description:
Start off with a short, fun, and perhaps sandbagged crux with great hand jams and awkward body position. That's where the good times end... The second half of the climb is dirty, tedious, and the rock quality is poor. Rotten roots and grime clog the wide cracks and it seems no amount of cleaning could save this thing. The anchor bolts are easy to miss (far out right on the upper slab. If you make it to the trees, you've gone to far).  
  
 Some users on other sites have made the case that the start of this route is much harder than the guidebook proposes. It definitely requires some solid hand crack technique. While I wouldn't argue with an upgrade, it's certainly no harder than 5.7

Farthest left route at Krack Rock. Starts up the fine-looking hand crack just before the trees.
Standard Rack with an emphasis on large hand size pieces. Easy to protect throughout, except when the crack becomes clogged with roots and grime. Crux protects beautifully. Two-bolt anchor at the top right, easy to miss.

Lower half is the crux. the holds and gear appear as you go.

lower center of Krack Rock, right of Lonely Thunder, left of Popsickle.

standard rack to #3, extra in small cams (optional #4).

Shares anchor with Popsickle

a worthwhile 5.8/5.9 if you have not tried it. 
 Starts in big black streak, leans left, finish on Fairy Ring anchor.

left of Koko crack, right of corner with thin finger crack- which is quite good for the little inside corner-maybe 10b.
standard trad rack to #3.

Climb a finger crack to a ledge then stem and lie back up the obvious left-facing corner through the crux. Finish on easier terrain. 



Left side of the Krack Rock, first route that climbs to the obvious big ledge 10 feet up. 

Standard rack, extra finger sizes.

climbs.name: On Sight Inc.
climbs.fa: Peder Ourom, Jens Ourom & Harry Young, 2013

content.description:
A fun hand crack splitting the face to the left of Fairy Ring (5.6). Bottom section can be a tad seepy adding to the challenge low-down.

For a 10a finger crack variation, cut right about 1/3rd of the way up.


Left side of Krack Rock

SR, 0.5"-4"

climbs.name: On Sight Inc. (Finger crack variation)
climbs.fa: Peder Ourom, Jens Ourom, Harry Young, 2013

content.description:
The finger crack variation of the left leaning diagonal crack. This variation seemed so seperate from the route it shares a start with, I felt it needed its own page. 

Once at the first little ledge, head right towards the splitter finger crack. Great gear, great locks and sustained until the ledge. The best route at this crag in my opinion!



Climb the left leaning hand crack of On Sight Inc. until you reach the finger crack.

The splitter eats BD .3 to .75. Doubles in those sizes were useful for the whole climb.

a decent 5.7 crack, mostly hands. The long angling left one that is right of Koko crack. 
 This name spelling is in 90's guide, it is popsicle in the select book.

right of Koko crack. Same anchor
standard rack, extra in hand size.

this is the next crack right of Fairy Ring and finishes on that one. 
 It is mostly a hand crack leaning left ( like all the cracks on this lump) You will find better routes near by at the grade- laughing crack, cat crack and corner crack. But if it's all there is it's ok.

right of Fairy, left of a finger crack through a roof.
mostly hand to fist size cams, and some smaller cams work.
Krack Rock is a trailside crag with numerous cracks ranging from 5.6 to 5.10c.  Top ropes can be set by scrambling up on the left (dirty 4th class).
